{{EngvarB|date=February 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=February 2014}} {{Infobox book | name = Farmageddon | image = File:Farmageddon (book).jpg | image_size = | alt = | caption = | author = {{Plainlist| * [[Philip Lymbery]] * [[Isabel Oakeshott]] }} | country = | subject = | genre = | publisher = [[Bloomsbury Publishing|Bloomsbury]] | pub_date = {{Start date|2014}} | pages = | awards = | isbn = 978-1-40884-644-5 | oclc = 900181396 | dewey = | congress = | wikisource = | notes = | exclude_cover = }} [[File:Confined-animal-feeding-operation.jpg|thumb|Dairy ''[[Concentrated Animal Feeding Operation]]'']] [[File:Gestation crates 5.jpg|thumb|A [[Pig|sow]] will often stay in a [[gestation crate]] for the four-month period of her pregnancy.]] [[File:Farrowingcrate.png|thumb|A nursing sow in a farrowing crate.]] [[File:Heogan Fishmeal Factory, Bressay - geograph.org.uk - 1444467.jpg|thumb|Fish meal factory]] '''''Farmageddon: The True Cost of Cheap Meat''''' is a 2014 non-fiction book by [[Philip Lymbery]] and [[Isabel Oakeshott]]. It surveys the effects of [[industrial livestock production]] and industrial [[fish farming]] around the world. The book is the result of Lymbery's investigations for which he travelled the world over three years. Isabel Oakeshott is the political editor of ''[[The Sunday Times]]'', Philip Lymbery is CEO of [[Compassion in World Farming]]. The book was published by [[Bloomsbury Publishing|Bloomsbury]].
==Synopsis== The thesis examined in the book is that globalised production chains of industrialised agricultural systems negatively affect farmed animals, human health, the countryside, rivers and oceans, biodiversity in rainforests and many of the world's poorest people. The authors seek to shed light on the conditions in intensive agriculture which, according to them, often differ from the image that the industry wants to sell to the public. Intensification in animal farming goes along with a growing demand of cropland to grow animal feed – factory farming is thus not a means to save space.<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/books/2014/feb/02/farmageddon-philip-lymber-review-farming Farmageddon by Philip Lymbery with Isabel Oakeshott – review], Lucy Siegle, ''The Observer'', 2 February 2014</ref><ref name=telegraph10620308>[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/books/bookreviews/10620308/Farmageddon-by-Philip-Lymbery-with-Isabel-Oakeshott-review.html Farmageddon by Philip Lymbery with Isabel Oakeshott, review], Tom Fort, ''The Daily Telegraph'', 10 February 2014</ref> They argue consequently that to feed the world population factory farming is not the solution but a threat, not least since more than a third of the world's arable harvests are being used to supply farmed animals.<ref name=guardian20140129>[https://www.theguardian.com/books/2014/jan/29/farmageddon-cost-cheap-meat-lymbery-review Farmageddon: The True Cost of Cheap Meat by Philip Lymbery – review], Tristram Stuart, ''The Guardian'', 31 January 2014</ref> According to the book the consumer price of [[cheap meat]] does not include the overall costs of industrial meat production.<ref>[http://www.philiplymbery.com/farmageddon-book/ Farmageddon], website of Philip Lymbery</ref>
The reader follows Lymbery's journey from his start in California's [[Central Valley (California)|Central Valley]]. There he finds dairies where 10,000 cows can be milked at once.<ref>[http://www.philiplymbery.com/farmageddon-book/ Farmageddon, first chapter (online), p.19]</ref> He travels to enormous piggeries in China and visits the [[fish meal|fishmeal industry]] of Peru, which converts millions of tonnes of anchovies to fishmeal for supplying the livestock industry with feed.<ref>[https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/books/reviews/farmageddon-by-philip-lymbery-with-isabel-oakeshott-book-review-9112828.html Farmageddon by Philip Lymbery (with Isabel Oakeshott): Book review], Mike McCarthy, ''The Independent'', 7 February 2014</ref> In Taiwan he visits a farm (labelled "organic") where 300,000 laying hens are being starved and held in batteries. A visit is paid to the Chesapeake Bay in Virginia, US where he finds the marine ecosystem impacted by waste from the poultry industry. The author talks to a community in Mexico in an area dominated by pig sheds. There he documents a lake of effluent and air and water pollution, and discusses the outbreak of swine flu.<ref name=telegraph10620308/>
One chapter of ''Farmageddon'' is dedicated to the question "What happened to the vet?" Lymbery says that veterinarians work in an industry with an "inbuild flaw". He states that veterinarians often comply with the industrialization of animals, for example in the prophylactic use of antibiotics which are applied in the [[mass production]] [[meat industry|of animals]], eggs and milk instead of demanding a different (pasture-based) agricultural system. According to Lymbery veterinarians should not support systems that are "inherently bad for animal welfare", which allegedly is the case in "mass production of broiler chickens, caged production of eggs, the large-scale permanent housing of dairy cows (so-called mega dairies) and highly intensive pig production where mothering pigs are kept in confinement where they can't turn around for weeks at a time".<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2014/jan/20/vets-industrial-agri-business "Have vets really sold out to industrial agri-business?"], Lucy Siegle, ''The Guardian'', 19 January 2014</ref>
In order to prevent ''Farmageddon'' the authors come up with suggestions for consumers, policy makers and farmers: Consumers should eat less meat. Fish should be fed to people rather than converted into fishmeal. Animals should be fed with grass and animal farming should be a pasture-based system. These changes would save resources by reducing the competition of humans and animals for food and land.<ref name=telegraph10620308/>
==Reception== [[Tristram Stuart]] wrote in a review for ''[[The Guardian]]'' that although he is critical towards the "orthodoxy that large-scale farms and industrial agricultural technology are inherently wrong", "this catalogue of devastation will convince anyone who doubts that industrial farming is causing ecological meltdown".<ref name=guardian20140129/>
==See also== *''[[We are fed up]]''

'''Fonds Coislin''' ({{lang-fr|'''Le fonds Coislin'''}}) is a collection (or [[fonds]]) of Greek manuscripts acquired by [[Pierre Séguier]], but named after [[Henri Charles du Cambout de Coislin|Henri-Charles de Coislin]], its second owner. It is now held in the [[Bibliothèque nationale de France|National Library of France]], as one of three fonds of Greek manuscripts: ''fonds grec'', ''fonds Coislin'', and ''supplément grec''.
[[File:Seguier.jpg|thumb|widthpx|Pierre Seguier painted by [[Henri Testelin]] (ca. 1668)]]
== History of collection ==
The majority of these manuscripts were collected between 1643 and 1653, by Père Athanase the Rhetor, who bought them for [[Pierre Séguier]] (1588–1672), chancellor of France from 1635. Athanase bought the manuscripts in [[Cyprus]], [[Constantinople]], [[Mount Athos]], and in other territories bordering the northern and western [[Aegean Sea|Aegean]].<ref> Henri Omont, {{fr icon}} ''Missions archéologiques françaises en Orient au XVII<sup>e</sup> et XVIII<sup>e</sup> siècles'', (Paris: Imprimerie Nationale, 1902), pp. 1–26.</ref>
The collection contains almost 400 manuscripts. Athanase collected more than 300 manuscripts (probably 358) personally. After Séguier's death, all this collection was inherited by his grandson, Henri-Charles de Coislin (1664–1732), [[bishop of Metz]].<ref>[[Henri Omont]], [https://archive.org/stream/inventairesomma00manugoog#page/n25/mode/2up ''Inventaire sommaire des manuscrits grecs de la Bibliothèque nationale''], p. XIII</ref> He gave it to the Benedictine monks of [[Saint-Germain-des-Prés]] in [[Paris]].
[[File:Bernard de Montfaucon - Imagines philologorum.jpg|thumb|right|Bernard de Montfaucon]] The first catalogue of this collection, the Coislin catalogue, was made in 1715, in which 42 manuscripts were described ([[Bernard de Montfaucon]], ''Bibliotheca Coisliniana olim Segueriana'', Paris: Ludovicus Guerin & Carolus Robustel, 1715). A large part of the collection was burned in 1793, and in 1795 ''Fonds Coislin'' was deposited in the [[National Library of France]], where it has been held until the present day. A few manuscripts, bought by Russians in time of [[Catherine II of Russia|Catherine II]], now are held at [[Saint Petersburg]], (s.v. Dubrowski).<ref>[[Frederick William Hall]], ''A Companion to Classical Texts'', Oxford: [[Clarendon Press]], 1968, p. 306.</ref>
One of the best known manuscripts of the collection is the fragmentary uncial [[Codex Coislinianus]]. The collection also includes [[Minuscule 35]] (Coislin 199), now considered to be one of the best witness of the [[Byzantine text-type]], and the basis for ''The Gospel According to John in the Byzantine Tradition'' (Deutsche Bibelgesellschaft, Stuttgart 2007). The collection also includes further witnesses to the text of the New Testament, as well as to the [[Septuagint]], [[Josephus]], and other ancient, and medieval authors.
== Some manuscripts ==
* [[Minuscule 36|Coislinianus 20]] — [[Gospel]]s (Gregory-Aland 36) * [[Minuscule 41|Coislinianus 24]] — Gospel of Matthew and Mark (Gregory-Aland 41) * [[Uncial 056|Coislinianus 26]] — [[Acts of Apostles]], [[Pauline epistles]] (Gregory-Aland 056) * Coislinianus 131 — part of Pseudo-Josephus report on Jesus Christus and early Christianity * Coislinianus 149 — [[Diodorus Siculus]] * [[Minuscule 35|Coislinianus 199]] — (Gregory-Aland 35) * [[Minuscule 38|Coislinianus 200]] — [[Gospels]] (Gregory-Aland 38) * Coislinianus 305 — Chronicon of [[George Hamartolus]] (with fragments of [[Papias of Hierapolis|Papias]]) * Coislinianus 311 — [[Alexiad]] * Coislinianus 345 — Codex Unicus of the Homeric lexicographer [[Apollonius the Sophist]] * [[Codex Coislinianus 386|Coislinianus 386]] — [[On the Soul]] * Coislinianus 387 — manuscript of [[Iliad]]<ref>{{Cite book | author = Pagès Cebrián Cebrian | title = Mythographus Homericus: estudi i edició comentada | url = http://www.tdx.cat/bitstream/handle/10803/5546/jpc1de1.pdf;jsessionid=B30804E832586C43B5EA96FECB06E448.tdx2?sequence=1 | publisher = | location = Barcelona | year = 2007 | page = 20 | isbn = 9788469073667}}</ref>

{{Infobox software | name = FreeOTFE | logo = FreeOTFE-logo-32x32.png | screenshot = FreeOTFE.png | caption = FreeOTFE running on Windows XP | developer = Sarah Dean | latest_release_version = 5.21 | latest_release_date = {{Start date and age|2010|2|7|df=yes}} | operating_system = [[Microsoft Windows]] and [[Windows Mobile]] | programming language = [[C (programming language)|C]], [[Delphi (programming language)|Delphi]] (GUI) | genre = [[Disk encryption software]] | language = Croatian, Czech, English, French, German, Greek, Italian, Japanese, Russian and Spanish | license = [[Free and open-source software]] that requires [[attribution (copyright)|attribution]]<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20130522094657/http://www.freeotfe.org/docs/Main/licence.htm FreeOTFE license]</ref> | website = {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130531062457/http://freeotfe.org/ |date=May 31, 2013 |title=FreeOTFE }} }} [[File:FreeOTFE4PDA.png|240px|thumbnail|right|FreeOTFE4PDA]] '''FreeOTFE''' is a discontinued [[open-source software|open source]] computer program for [[on-the-fly encryption|on-the-fly]] [[disk encryption]] (OTFE). On [[Microsoft Windows]], and [[Windows Mobile]] (using FreeOTFE4PDA), it can create a [[RAM drive|virtual drive]] within a file or [[Disk partitioning|partition]], to which anything written is automatically encrypted before being stored on a computer's [[hard disk drive|hard]] or [[USB flash drive|USB]] drive. It is similar in function to other disk encryption programs including [[TrueCrypt]] and Microsoft's [[BitLocker]].<ref>David A. Karp, Windows Vista annoyances, O'Reilly Media, Inc., 2008, {{ISBN|0-596-52762-4}}, page 5.</ref>
The author, Sarah Dean, went absent as of 2011. The FreeOTFE website is unreachable as of June 2013 and the domain name is now registered by a [[domain squatter]]. The original program can be downloaded from [http://sourceforge.net/projects/freeotfe.mirror/ a mirror at Sourceforge]. In June 2014, a [[Fork (software development)|fork]] of the project now named LibreCrypt appeared on [[GitHub]].<ref>[https://github.com/t-d-k/librecrypt LibreCrypt on GitHub]</ref>
== Overview ==
''FreeOTFE'' was initially released by Sarah Dean in 2004, and was the first open source code disk encryption system that provided a modular architecture allowing 3rd parties to implement additional algorithms if needed. Older FreeOTFE licensing required that any modification to the program be placed in the [[public domain]]. This does not conform technically to section 3 of the [[Open Source definition]]. Newer program licensing omits this condition. The FreeOTFE license has not been approved by the [http://opensource.org/licenses/alphabetical Open Source Initiative] and is not certified to be labeled with the open-source certification mark.
This software is compatible with Linux encrypted volumes (e.g. [[LUKS]], [[cryptoloop]], [[dm-crypt]]), allowing data encrypted under Linux to be read (and written) freely. It was the first open source transparent disk encryption system to support [[Windows Vista]] and PDAs.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20130305192701/http://freeotfe.org/docs/Main/version_history.htm FreeOTFE version history]</ref><ref>Michael Mandaville, Citizen-Soldier Handbook: 101 Ways Every American Can Fight Terrorism, Dog Ear Publishing, 2009 {{ISBN|1-59858-671-8}}, page 253.</ref><ref>Gregory B. White, Wm. Arthur Conklin, Dwayne Williams, Roger L. Davis, Chuck Cothren, ''CompTIA Security+ All-in-One Exam Guide'', Second Edition, McGraw Hill Professional, 2008, {{ISBN|0-07-160127-9}}, page 103.</ref><ref>Bryan Burns, Jennifer Stisa Granick, Steve Manzuik, Paul Guersch, Dave Killion, Nicolas Beauchesne, ''Security power tools'', O'Reilly Media, Inc., 2007, {{ISBN|0-596-00963-1}}, page 523.</ref>
Optional [[two-factor authentication]] using [[smart card]]s and/or [[hardware security module]]s (HSMs, also termed [[security tokens]])<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20090401045551/http://www.freeotfe.org/docs/pkcs11_support.htm Security Token/Smartcard Support]</ref> was introduced in v4.0, using the [[PKCS11|PKCS#11]] (Cryptoki) standard developed by [[RSA Laboratories]].
''FreeOTFE'' also allows any number of "hidden volumes" to be created, giving [[plausible deniability]] and [[deniable encryption]], and also has the option of encrypting full partitions or disks (but not the system partition).<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20130124091508/http://freeotfe.org/docs/Main/advanced_topics.htm#level_3_heading_2 Partition/Entire Disk Based Volumes]</ref>
==Portable use==
[[File:FreeOTFEExplorer.png|thumb|left|FreeOTFE Explorer allows access to encrypted disks, without installing any drivers.]]
FreeOTFE can be used in "portable" (or "traveller") mode, which allows it to be kept on a USB drive or other portable media, together with its encrypted data, and carried around. This allows it to be used under [[Microsoft Windows]] without installation of the complete program to "mount" and access the encrypted data through a virtual disk.
The use of this mode requires installing [[device drivers]] (at least temporarily) to create virtual disks, and as a consequence administrator rights are needed to start this traveller mode. As with most open source software that uses device drivers, the user must enable test signing<ref>[https://social.technet.microsoft.com/Forums/windows/en-US/4c0e8b2a-a543-4c49-9629-8c4538acd0b5/what-is-windows-7-test-mode?forum=w7itproinstall What is Windows 7 Test Mode]</ref> when running Windows Vista x64 and Windows 7 x64 systems.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20130124091539/http://freeotfe.org/docs/Main/impact_of_kernel_driver_signing.htm Additional Information for Windows Vista x64 and Windows 7 x64 Users]</ref>
===Driverless operation===
Packaged with FreeOTFE is another program called "FreeOTFE Explorer",<ref name="explorer">[https://web.archive.org/web/20130305192649/http://freeotfe.org/main_explorer_differences.html FreeOTFE v. FreeOTFE Explorer Comparison]</ref> which provides a ''driverless system'' that allows encrypted disks to be used without administrator rights.
This allows FreeOTFE encrypted data to be used on (for example) public computers found in libraries or computer kiosks ([[interactive kiosk]]s), where administrator rights are unavailable.
Unlike FreeOTFE, FreeOTFE Explorer does not provide on-the-fly encryption through a virtual drive.<ref name="explorer"/> Instead it lets files be stored and extracted from encrypted disk images, in a similar manner as [[ZIP (file format)|ZIP]] and [[RAR (file format)|RAR]] archives, by using a [[Windows Explorer]] like interface.
== Algorithms implemented == Due to its architecture, FreeOTFE provides great flexibility to the user with its encryption options.
=== Ciphers === FreeOTFE implements several ciphers, including: {{col-begin|width=auto}} {{col-2}} * [[Advanced Encryption Standard|AES]] * [[Blowfish (cipher)|Blowfish]] * [[CAST5]] / [[CAST6]] * [[Data Encryption Standard|DES]] / [[Triple DES]] {{col-2}} * [[MARS (cryptography)|MARS]] * [[RC6]] * [[Serpent (cipher)|Serpent]] * [[Twofish]] {{col-end}}
It includes all [[National Institute of Standards and Technology]] (NIST) [[Advanced Encryption Standard]] (AES) finalists, and all ciphers can be used with multiple different keylengths.
==== Cipher modes ==== FreeOTFE originally offered encryption using [[cipher-block chaining]] (CBC) with encrypted salt-sector initialization vector ([[ESSIV]]), though from v3.00 introduced [[LRW#LRW|LRW]] and also the more secure [[disk encryption theory#XTS|XTS]] mode, which supersedes LRW in the [[IEEE P1619]] standard for disk encryption.
=== Hashes === As with its cipher options, FreeOTFE offers many different hash algorithms:
{{col-begin|width=auto}} {{col-4}} * [[MD2 (cryptography)|MD2]] * [[MD4]] * [[MD5]] * [[RIPEMD-160|RIPEMD-128]] {{col-4}} * [[RIPEMD-160]] * [[RIPEMD|RIPEMD-224]] * [[RIPEMD|RIPEMD-320]] * [[SHA-1]] {{col-4}} * [[SHA-224]] * [[SHA-256]] * [[SHA-384]] * [[SHA-512]] {{col-4}} * [[Tiger (hash)|Tiger]] * [[WHIRLPOOL|Whirlpool]] {{col-end}}
== See also == {{Portal|Cryptography}}
* [[Disk encryption]] * [[Disk encryption software]] * [[On-the-fly encryption]] * [[Comparison of disk encryption software]]

{{EngvarB|date=August 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2014}} {{Infobox writer |name = George Elder Davie |image = George Davie 1.jpg |caption = George Davie with Dr. Vincent Hope in 1996 |birth_name = |pseudonym = G.E. Davie |birth_date = {{birth date|df=yes|1912|03|18}} |birth_place = [[Dundee]], Scotland, UK |death_date = {{death date and age|df=yes|2007|03|20|1912|03|18}} |death_place = [[Sutton Veny]], Wiltshire, UK |occupation = Writer, philosopher, academic |nationality = Scottish |genre = non-fiction, philosophy, [[James Frederick Ferrier]] |influences = |influenced = |signature = |notableworks = |spouse=Elspeth Mary Dryer |children=one daughter }} '''George Elder Davie''' (1912–2007) was a prominent Scottish philosopher whose well-received book, ''[[The Democratic Intellect]]'' (1961), concerns the treatment of philosophy in 19th century Scottish universities. == Life == He was born at no. 4 Baxter Park Terrace, [[Dundee]] on 18 March 1912. His father, George Myles Davie was a [[pharmacist]] and chemistry teacher, and his mother was Isabella Calder Elder. He married Elspeth Mary Dryer, an art teacher, on 5 October 1944 at [[Bonnyrigg]] Church in [[Midlothian]]. [[Elspeth Davie]] later became a respected writer and was awarded the [[Katherine Mansfield]] Prize in 1978.According to [[The Herald (Glasgow)|The Herald]] Obituary, 23 March 2007, but this does not appear to be the New Zealand Katherine Mansfield Prize. They had one daughter with whom he resided at [[Sutton Veny]], Wiltshire at the time of his death on 20 March 2007.Births, marriages and deaths information available at the General Register Office for Scotland, Scotlands People Centre in Edinburgh, and also at http://scotlandspeople.gov.uk == Career == * George Davie was educated at the [[High School of Dundee]] after which he was offered a place at [[Oxford University]] but turned it down in favour of [[Edinburgh University]] where graduated MA in 1935 with a [[first class honours degree]] in [[Classics]].[[Obituary]] in [[The Independent]], Thursday, 29 March 2007. * In 1939 he was appointed assistant lecturer in the Department of Philosophy at Edinburgh University. He was assistant to [[Norman Kemp Smith]] and he later co-edited the latter's collected papers.''The Credibility of Divine Existence: The collected papers of Norman Kemp Smith'', edited by A. J. D. Porteus, R. D. Maclennan and G.E. Davie. London: Macmillan, 1967. * His war service between 1941 and 1945 was in the [[Royal Corps of Signals]]. * After the war, he was appointed lecturer in philosophy at [[Queens University, Belfast]] where he remained till 1959 when he returned to [[Edinburgh University]] as Lecturer. He retired in 1982 and was appointed Reader Emeritus at Edinburgh in 1987. * In 1953 he was awarded the degree of DLitt by [[Edinburgh University]] for his thesis, "A Scotch Metaphysics – the Theory of Knowledge in the Scottish Universities 1730–1860". This thesis was published in 2000 under the title, ''The Scotch Metaphysics : a Century of Enlightenment in Scotland.'' * A Conference was held in his honour at [[Edinburgh University]] on 13 to 15 September 1996. It was entitled: 'The Legacy of Empiricism, A Conference in Honour of George Davie', and held in the David Hume Tower. On Sunday 15 September 1996, he delivered a conference paper entitled “Five Philosophical Theses from [[James Frederick Ferrier|Ferrier]]". In spite of suffering blindness by that time he held the rapt attention of his audience for an hour and a half. == Honours == * Honorary Doctorate at [[Dundee University]] * Honorary Doctorate at [[Edinburgh University]], awarded 1995.{{cite news |url=http://www.heraldscotland.com/news/12097075.EDINBURGH/ |title=Doctor Honoris Causa |work=The Herald |date=13 July 1995 |accessdate=18 December 2016}} * Fellow of [[the Royal Society of Edinburgh]] * Fellow of the [[Educational Institute of Scotland]] * [http://www.saltiresociety.org.uk/view_item.aspx?item_id=3700&open2=false Andrew Fletcher of Saltoun Award] of [[the Saltire Society]] * [[Festschrift]] published in his honour by Dr. Vincent Hope in 1984''Philosophers of the Scottish Enlightenment''. Edited by Vincent Hope. Edinburgh: Edinburgh University Press, 1984. == ''The Democratic Intellect'' == In this book, Davie deals with the struggle during the 19th century in Scotland to maintain a generalist form of education which is not only philosophical but also scientific, humanistic and democratic. The book has been described as "a thesis about liberal education – pursued by a micro-historical investigation of the culture and academic politics of Scotland's universities in the 19th century. More than 40 years on, the book's discussions of the restriction of academic independence by centralisation, inter-university competition for prestige, research versus teaching and even versus scholarship, notions of abandoning moral discourse for ill-examined claims regarding scientific advance, are still relevant."[[Obituary]] in [[The Independent]], Thursday, 29 March 2007.
Davie's somewhat prolix style of writing is exemplified here:
“It is possible to confirm still further the importance which this ideal of a philosophical education had for the Scots if we turn from the achieved pattern of national pedagogy to the plans which were being mooted for its development. What these plans reveal – until well on in the nineteenth century – is the remarkable hold on the country of the belief in the possibility of general education through philosophy. Not that the Scots had any dislike of professional accomplishment; on the contrary, they admired it even to excess, and were eager for the introduction into their educational system of training centres for higher education and specialisation in the new subjects. But the distinctive mark of their thinking about these matters and of the organised projects it inspired was that they wanted to retain philosophy as a compulsory part of what we would now call secondary education (fifteen to nineteen), and that admission to the specialist schools – though it was to be granted early – nevertheless would require, as a preliminary, philosophical education in the old style.”''The Democratic Intellect'', second edition, 1964, paperback edition, 1981, p.20. == Publications == * ''[[The Democratic Intellect]]: Scotland and her Universities in the Nineteenth Century.'' Edinburgh: University Press, 1961, 1964 and 1999. * ''The Scottish Enlightenment.'' London Historical Association, 1981. * ''[[The Crisis of the Democratic Intellect]]: The Problem of Generalism and Specialisation in Twentieth-Century Scotland.'' Edinburgh: Polygon, 1986. * 'Scottish Philosophy and Specialisation: a Long View'. ''Occasional papers of the Royal Society of Edinburgh'', nos. 2–6. Edinburgh: 1985, p. 41–56. * ''The Scottish Enlightenment and Other Essays''. Edinburgh: Polygon, 1991. * ''A Passion for Ideas: Essays on the Scottish Enlightenment 2''. Edinburgh: Polygon, 1994. * ''The Scotch Metaphysics : a Century of Enlightenment in Scotland.'' London & New York: Routledge, 2000. == Sources == * [[Obituary]] in [[The Independent]]: https://www.independent.co.uk/news/obituaries/george-davie-442290.html * [[Obituary]] in [[The Herald (Glasgow)|The Herald]]: http://www.heraldscotland.com/george-davie-1.854872 * [[Edinburgh University]] [[obituary]]: http://www.philosophy.ed.ac.uk/documents/GeorgeDavieobituary.pdf ==References== {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Davie, George Elder}} [[Category:1912 births]] [[Category:2007 deaths]] [[Category:People from Dundee]] [[Category:People educated at the High School of Dundee]] [[Category:Alumni of the University of Edinburgh]] [[Category:Scottish writers]] [[Category:Scottish educators]] [[Category:Fellows of the Royal Society of Edinburgh]] [[Category:Scottish philosophers]] [[Category:Royal Corps of Signals soldiers]] [[Category:Academics of Queen's University Belfast]] [[Category:Academics of the University of Edinburgh]]

'''Henning Arnisaeus''' (Arniseus) (1570–1636) was a German physician and moral philosopher.<ref name = Scholasticon>{{fr icon}} http://www.scholasticon.fr/Database/Scholastiques_fr.php?ID=172</ref> He is now known for his writings on political theory.
==Life==
He was born in [[Schlanstedt]], a village in the present-day [[Harz (district)|Harz district]] of Germany, near [[Huy, Germany|Huy]].<ref>{{de icon}} http://www.schlanstedt.de/chronik.php?start=1&ppp=300</ref> He studied philosophy and medicine at the Protestant [[University of Helmstedt]] from 1589.<ref>{{de icon}} [https://books.google.com/books?id=PCNN_blc77kC&pg=PA46&lpg=PA46&dq=Arnisaeus+Helmstedt&source=bl&ots=mg9e8Uqc1X&sig=bTp2RXqwBmBw1gdN6PYe-lJRZTY&hl=en&ei=euN8TJ_pM8bd4Abtz9neBg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=9&ved=0CEcQ6AEwCA#v=onepage&q=Arnisaeus%20Helmstedt&f=false Herbert Jaumann, ''Handbuch Gelehrtenkultur der Frühen Neuzeit'' (2004), p. 46]</ref> After travels in England and France, he became court physician to [[Christian IV of Denmark]].<ref name = Scholasticon/>
==Views== At Helmstedt, Arnisaeus became a pupil of [[Cornelius Martini]], a [[Lutheran]] metaphysician who also influenced [[Hermann Conring]].<ref>{{de icon}} http://www.kirchenlexikon.de/m/martini_c.shtml</ref><ref>http://www.ferratermora.org/essa_suarez-modern.html</ref> He used an [[Aristotelianism|Aristotelian]] analysis to distinguish in political thought between the ''[[civitas]]'' and the ''[[res publica]]'', in a critique of [[Jean Bodin]], [[Johannes Althusius]], Busius (Paulus Buis or Buys, died 1617), and [[Bartholomäus Keckermann]].<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=yBY8M6xCvysC&pg=PA209&lpg=PA209&dq=arnisaeus+Aristotelian&source=bl&ots=zzqwMlc8Oe&sig=4-iIlwFhXo25aWT4Jx6hcnGol5E&hl=en&ei=u-58TJDXLsiN4gajzIyRBg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CBUQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=arnisaeus%20Aristotelian&f=false Martin van Gelderen, ''Aristotelians, Monarchomachs and Republicans: Sovereignty and respublica mixta in Dutch and German Political Thought, 1580-1650'', p. 209, in Martin van Gelderen, Quentin Skinner (editors), ''Republicanism and Constitutionalism in Early Modern Europe'' (2005).]</ref> He particularly criticized Bodin's strictures on [[mixed government]] in his 1606 ''Doctrina politica''.<ref>http://www.potowmack.org/mcilwain.html</ref> That work also incorporated [[Tacitean]] ideas, under the influence of [[Arnold Clapmar]], within the Aristotelian and humanist framework he proposed, attacking the [[Ramist]] critics of Aristotle.<ref>Richard Tuck, ''Philosophy and Government 1572-1651'' (1993), p. 126.</ref>
While Arnisaeus saw a role for [[civil society]], he did not admit any qualification of the power of the 'magistrate'. In 1610 in ''De jure majestatis'' he took Bodin's part against the mixed state; even so, in relation to [[Holy Roman Empire]] and its institutions he admitted that sovereignty could in practical terms be distributed among several authorities.<ref>http://www.answers.com/topic/theory-of-sovereignty</ref> He is therefore classed as an 'absolutist', a supporter of [[absolute monarchy]].<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=6WxvOUQbwLQC&pg=PA167&lpg=PA167&dq=Althusius+Arnisaeus&source=bl&ots=d7hYAStUy3&sig=KymDq9eBCTaXnmRCjem2GQIfy_g&hl=en&ei=0vp8TJm6JcqL4gbz-p24Bg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CBUQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=Althusius%20Arnisaeus&f=false Conal Condren, Stephen Gaukroger, Ian Hunter, ''The Philosopher in Early Modern Europe: the nature of a contested identity'' (2006), p. 167.]</ref> Theoretically, in the case of the Empire, he argued that sovereignty lay with the [[Prince-elector]]s.<ref>Richard Tuck, ''Philosophy and Government 1572-1651'' (1993), p. 124.</ref> This was very much a minority view among Germans, opposed by Althusius and Keckermann, as well as Hermann Kirchner, Daniel Otto, and Tobias Paurmeister, all of whom took the view that the Emperor was a true monarch.<ref>http://www.austlii.edu.au/au/journals/AJLH/2004/9.html</ref>
Against Althusius, he argued that (true) monarchy could be compromised by concessions of power that distorted the 'form' of the state, and that this was a more accurate description of the actual French state.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=TiVKeH-cMPUC&pg=PA314&lpg=PA314&dq=Althusius+Arnisaeus&source=bl&ots=w80ai5k3an&sig=HEIj_L-_pCRJEF2ady68lWOBdcQ&hl=en&ei=nfx8TJ6FDZC74Aa7p6G_Bg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=4&ved=0CCIQ6AEwAw#v=onepage&q=Althusius%20Arnisaeus&f=false James Henderson Burns, J. H. Burns, Mark Goldie. ''The Cambridge History of Political Thought, 1450-1700'' (1995), p. 314.]</ref>
Arnisaeus died in Copenhagen.
His ideas were influential in the setting up of [[Danish absolutism]].<ref>http://www.cliothemis.com/Elegant-Jurisprudence-in</ref>
==Works== [[File:Doctrina Politica 1651.jpg|thumb|right|Title page of the 1651 edition of the ''Doctrina politica''.]] * Doctrina politica in genuinam methodum, quae est Aristotelis, reducta (1606) * De constitutione et partibus Metaphysicae, (Frankfurt, 1606) * Epitome metaphysicae (1606) * De jure majestatis (Frankfurt, 1610) * ''Vindiciae pro Aristotele et Sanioribus quibusque philosophis contra Thomae Rhaedi Scoti pervigilia & dissertationem elencticam de subjecto metaphysicae & natura entis assertae'' (Frankfurt, 1611). During the period 1608-9 he made a public disputation on metaphysics, with the Scottish philosopher and humanist [[Thomas Reid (humanist)|Thomas Reid]] (Rhaedus) who was at [[Rostock]].<ref>''[[Oxford Dictionary of National Biography]]'', Reid, Thomas (d. 1624), philosopher, translator, and founder of the first public reference library in Scotland by T. P. J. Edlin. {{DNBfirst|wstitle=Reid, Thomas (d.1624)}}</ref> This book was the written form of his reply to Reid. * De auctoritate principum in populum semper inviolabili (Frankfurt, 1612) * De subjectione et exemptione clericorum (Frankfurt, 1612) * De Republica, seu Relectionis politicae libri duo (Argentorati, 1636) * Opera politica (Strassburg, 1648).
==Notes== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[https://books.google.com/books?id=Tie0hkcrpg4C&pg=PA85&lpg=PA85&dq=%22Arnisaeus,+Henning%22&source=bl&ots=Hr79W7Q525&sig=lHCcrTUQrEk7M_jXcalWzGBbyo0&hl=en&ei=at98TKGbIIL_4AaGm6m_Bg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=6&ved=0CCoQ6AEwBTgU#v=onepage&q=%22Arnisaeus%2C%20Henning%22&f=false ''Index librorum prohibitorum: 1600-1966'', by Jesús Martínez de Bujanda, Marcella Richter] *[[:de:s:ADB:Arnisaeus, Henning]] *{{de icon}} http://www.philso.uni-augsburg.de/web2/Politik1/arnis.html
{{Authority control}}

'''Imperativus Pro Infinitivo''' (IPI) is a [[Syntax|syntactical feature]] in which a verbal form superficially resembling the [[imperative mood|imperative]] is realized, instead of the expected [[infinitive]].
The Imperativus Pro Infinitivo is a remarkable feature of, for example the [[Frisian languages]].
* North Frisian (Mooring): Ik häi änjörsne niinj lust än mååg seelew wat tu ääsen klåår. * Sater Frisian: Ik hiede jêrsene neen lûst on moakje selwen wet to iten kloar. * West(erlauwer) Frisian: Ik hie juster gjin nocht en meitsje sels wat te iten klear.
The sentences reads in English "Yesterday I did not feel like making dinner myself".

'''Jang Hyeongwang''' (장현광; 1554 – September 15, 1637) was a [[Korea]]n [[Joseon Dynasty]]s politician and educator, as well as a [[Confucian|Neo-Confucian]] scholar. Scholars successor of [[Jeong gu]] and teacher of [[Heo Mok]] and [[Yun Hyu]]. His pen name was Yeoheon (여헌).

{{lang-bn|খাজা নাজিমুদ্দীন}}; 19 July 1894 – 22 October 1964), {{small|[[Order of the Indian Empire|KCIE]], [[Companion of the Order of the Indian Empire|CIE]]}}, was a [[Bengali people|Bengali]] politician, [[Conservatism in Pakistan|conservative]] figure, and one of the leading [[List of Pakistan Movement activists|founding fathers]] of [[Pakistan]].{{Cite web |url=http://storyofpakistan.com/khawaja-nazimuddin |title=Khawaja Nazimuddin {{!}} Former Governor General of Pakistan |date=1 June 2003 |access-date=20 September 2016}} He is noted as being the first [[Bengalis|Bengali]] leader of Pakistan who led the country as [[Prime Minister of Pakistan|Prime Minister]] (1951–53), as well as the second [[Governor-General of Pakistan|Governor-General]] (1948–51).{{cite book |last=Sundararajan |first=Saroja |year=2010 |title=Kashmir Crisis: Unholy Anglo-Pak Nexus |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8xntfrAZkbsC&pg=PA375 |location=Delhi |publisher=Kalpaz Publications |pages=375– |isbn=978-81-7835-808-6}}http://opinion.bdnews24.com/bangla/archives/30517 Born into an [[Dhaka Nawab Family|aristocrat ''Nawab'']] family in [[Bengal Presidency|Bengal]] in 1894, he was educated at the [[Aligarh Muslim University]] before pursuing his education at the [[Cambridge University]] to secure his graduation. Upon returning, he started his political career on a [[All-India Muslim League|Muslim League]] platform where he primary focused on education causes in Bengal before leading the [[Independence of Pakistan|cause]] for separate Muslim homeland, Pakistan, under the leadership of [[Muhammad Ali Jinnah]]. From 1943–45, he served as the [[Prime Minister of Bengal]] and later becoming the [[List of current Pakistani chief ministers|Chief Minister]] in 1947 until 1948 when he ascended as Governor-General after Jinnah's passing. In 1951, he took over the control of the [[Government of Pakistan|government]] as Prime Minister of Pakistan upon the [[Assassination of liaqat ali khan|assassination]] of Liaquat Ali Khan, and relinquished the post of Governor-General to [[Malik Ghulam Muhammad|Sir Malik Ghulam]].{{cite web |url=http://www.pakistanherald.com/Profile/Khawaja-Nazimuddin-1176 |title= PakistanHerald.com : Khwaja Nazimuddin |accessdate=12 January 2012}} As Prime Minister, he struggled to run the [[Pakistani government|government]] effectively on the internal and foreign fronts, and thus he tenured for only two years. On the home front, he struggled to maintain [[Law and order in Pakistan|law and order]] in the country and instructed the [[Pakistani military|military]] to impose [[Martial law in Pakistan|martial law]] in [[Lahore]] due to [[1953 Lahore riots|religious riots]] and [[Economic stagnation|stagnation]]. He also faced a populist [[Bengali Language Movement|language movement]] in his native Bengal that eventually led to the shutdown of [[Government of East Pakistan]]. [[Foreign relations of Pakistan|Foreign relations]] with the [[Pakistan–United States relations|United States]], [[Pakistan–Soviet Union relations|Soviet Union]], [[Afghanistan–Pakistan relations|Afghanistan]], and [[India–Pakistan relations|India]] soured as [[Republican Party (Pakistan)|republicanism]] and [[Socialism in Pakistan|socialism]] gained popularity at home. Eventually, he was forced to step down in favor of diplomat [[Mohammad Ali Bogra]] by his own appointed Governor-General Sir Malik Ghulam and conceded defeat in [[East Pakistani legislative election, 1954|elections held in 1954]]. Upon retiring from [[Politics of Pakistan|national politics]], he suffered a brief illness and died in 1964. He was buried at a [[Mausoleum of three leaders|Mausoleum in Dhaka]].http://www.thedailystar.net/star-weekend/heritage/memory-the-three-leaders-1268149 ==Biography== ===Family background, early life would later played a vital role in [[Politics of Pakistan|national politics]] onwards.{{rp|76}}{{rp|xxx}} Being of Kashmiri-Bengali descent, his family spoke both [[Urdu language|Urdu]] and [[Bengali language|Bengali]].{{cite book |last=Coakley |first=John |year=2005 |orig-year=First published 2003 |title=The Territorial Management of Ethnic Conflict |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=nEqRAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA145 |publisher=Routledge |isbn=978-1-135-76442-5 |pages=145–146}} They were the first cousin of Nawab Khwaja Habibullah son of Nawab Sir [[Muhammadan Anglo-Oriental College|MAO College]] of the [[Aligarh Muslim University]] (AMU) in [[Aligarh, Uttar Pradesh|Uttar Pradesh]], India.{{cite book|title=Excerpts I|date=1949|url=https://books.google.com/?id=EfQpAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA449&dq=barrister-at-law.|accessdate=18 March 2017}} Nazimuddin secured his graduation with a [[Bachelor of Arts|BA degree]] in [[Sociology]] from AMU and was sent back to England to pursue higher education.{{cite book|last1=Khan|first1=Feisal|title=Islamic Banking in Pakistan: Shariah-Compliant Finance and the Quest to make Twilight: A Personal Record of the Partition of india by Major-General Shahid Hamid|date=1986|publisher=Pen and Sword, Amid|location=London, He was granted his [[Master of Arts|MA degree]] in [[English literature|English]] by Cambridge University.{{cite book|last1=Block|first1=Maxine|last2=Rothe|first2=Anna Herthe|last3=Candee|first3=Marjorie Dent|title=Current Biography Yearbook|publisher=H. Dunstable|url=http://www.luton-dunstable.co.uk/celebrities-know-connection-Dunstable/story-27967216-detail/story.html|website=Luton on Sunday|accessdate=21 January 2016|language=en-GB}} In 1947–49, Nazimuddin was granted the degree of [[Doctor of Law]]s by the Vice-Chancellor of [[University of Dhaka|Dhaka University]], Dr. [[Mahmud Hasan (academic)|Mahmud Hasan]].{{cite book|last1=Dacca|first1=University of|title=Report|publisher=Report|url=https://books.google.com/?id=JyDOAAAAMAAJ&dq=khawaja+nazimuddin+ba+degree&q=khawaja+nazimuddin+|accessdate=18 March 2017|language=en}}{{rp|161}} ==Politics== ===Public service and Independence movement=== {{Main|Prime Minister of Bengal}} Nazimuddin returned to India to join his brother [[Khwaja Shahabuddin|Khwaja Shahbuddin]] from England, taking interest in civil and public affairs that led him to join the [[Politics of Bangladesh|Bengali politics]].{{cite book |last=Ikram |first=S.M. |year=1995 |orig-year=First published 1992 |title=Indian Muslims and Partition of India |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7q9EubOYZmwC&pg=PA311 |edition=2nd |location=Delhi |publisher=Atlantic Publishers & Dist |pages=310–311 |isbn=978-81-7156-374-6}} Both brother joined the [[All India Muslim League|Muslim League]], and Nazimuddin successfully ran for the municipality election and elected as [[Mayor|Chairman]] of Dhaka Municipality from 1922 until 1929.{{cite web|url=http://www.storyofpakistan.com/person.asp?perid=P011|title=Khwaja Nazimuddin|publisher=Story of Pakistan |accessdate=12 January 2012}} During this time, he was appointed as [[Ministry of Education (Bangladesh)|Education minister]] and later secured a political appointment in [[Viceroy's Executive Council]] in 1934 which he served until 1937.{{cite book |last=Chatterji |first=Joya |year=2002 |orig-year=First Published 1994 |title=Bengal Divided: Hindu Communalism and Partition, 1932-1947 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=iDNAQcoVqoMC&pg=PA80 |publisher=Cambridge University Press |page=80 |isbn=978-0-521-52328-8}} He participated in regional elections held on 1937 on a Muslim League's platform but conceded his defeat in favor of [[A. K. Fazlul Huq|Fazlul Haq]] of [[Krishak Praja Party|Krishak Praja Part]] (KPP) who was appointed as [[Prime Minister of Bengal]], while assuming his personal role as member of the legislative assembly.{{cite book|last1=Rahman|first1=Syedur|title=Historical Dictionary of Bangladesh|date=2010|publisher=Scarecrow Press|location=Uk|isbn=9780810874534|pages=442|edition=4|url=https://books.google.com/?id=bJfcCPUr0OoC&pg=PA219&dq=khawaja+nazimuddin+politics+1934#v=onepage&q=khawaja%20nazimuddin%20politics%201934&f=false|accessdate=19 March 2017|language=en}}{{rp|219}}{{cite book|last1=Shibly|first1=Atful Hye|title=Abdul Matin Chaudhury (1895–1948) : trusted lieutenant of Mohammad Ali Jinnah|date=2011|publisher=Juned A. Choudhury|location=Dhaka|isbn=9789843323231|pages=69|language=en}}{{rp|69}} In the India Office Records, Political and Secret Department Records (1756–1950), Category L/P&S, Record 5/250, 3/79, one comes across the Fortnightly Report (February 1947) to the Viceroy by the then Governor of Punjab Sir Evan Jenkins. According to this report when inquired about the Pakistan project, Khawaja Nazimuddin candidly told him that ″he did not know what Pakistan means and that nobody in the Muslim League knew.″ This remark clearly shows that so few as six months before the creation of Pakistan, even senior Muslim League leaders had no clarity as to the basic features of the State they were asking for.{{efn|Further on this: Husain Haqqani, ″Magnificent Delusions,″ New York: Public Affairs, 2013, p. 17}} ===Home and Prime Minister of Bengal and Chief Minister of East Bengal (1940–47)=== Upon the formation of the [[coalition government]] in an agreement facilitated between [[All India Muslim League|Muslim League]] and the [[Praja Party|Krishak Praja Party]], Nazimuddin was appointed as the [[Ministry of Home Affairs (Bangladesh)|home minister]] under Haq's premiership., which he continued until 1943.{{cite book|last1=Chakrabarti|first1=Kunal|last2=Chakrabarti|first2=Shubhra|title=Historical Dictionary of the Bengalis|date=2004|publisher=Scarecrow Press|location=UK|isbn=9780810880245|edition=2|url=https://books.google.com/?id=QVOFAAAAQBAJ&pg=PA331&dq=khawaja+nazimuddin+politics+1934#v=onepage&q=khawaja%20nazimuddin%20politics%201934&f=false|accessdate=19 March 2017|language=en}}{{rp|331}} Due to his conservative elite position, he became close associate of [[Muhammad Ali Jinnah]], then-[[President of Pakistan Muslim League (N)|President]] of [[All India Muslim League|Muslim League]], who appointed him as a member of the executive committee to successfully promote Muslim League' party agenda and program that gained popularity in East Bengal.{{rp|332}}{{cite book|last1=Jaffrelot|first1=Christophe|title=The Pakistan Paradox: Instability And Resilience|publisher=Random House India|isbn=9788184007077|edition=5|url=https://books.google.com/?id=gQDzCQAAQBAJ&pg=PT72&dq=khawaja+nazimuddin+chief+minister#v=onepage&q=khawaja%20nazimuddin%20chief%20minister&f=false|accessdate=19 March 2017|language=en}} In 1940–41, Nazimuddin broke away from the coalition led by Premier [[A. K. Fazlul Huq|Fazlul Haq]] and decided to become a leader of the opposition, leading campaign against Haq's premiership and primarily focused on Bengali nationalism issues.{{rp|332}} In 1943, Nazimuddin took over the government from Premier Haq when the latter was dismissed by the [[Governor of Bengal|Governor]] [[John Herbert (Conservative politician)|John Herbert]] amid controversies surrounding in his political campaigns.{{cite book|last1=Partridge|first1=Roger|title=Bengal 1943: The Forgotten Famine: A Novel|publisher=Roger Partridge|isbn=9781909424005|url=https://books.google.com/?id=Ga7qAgAAQBAJ&pg=PT214&dq=khawaja+nazimuddin+bengal+minister+1943#v=onepage&q=khawaja%20nazimuddin%20bengal%20minister%201943&f=false|accessdate=19 March 2017|language=en}} During this time, Nazimuddin played a crucial political role for the [[Idea of Pakistan|cause]] for the separate Muslim homeland, [[Pakistan]].{{rp|332}} About his role, he was asked about the "Pakistan question" by British Governor [[Richard Casey, Baron Casey|Richard Casey]] in 1945 but he showed very little and no interests in discussing the existence of the [[Pakistan Movement|movement]] and reportedly quoting: he did not know what Pakistan means and nobody in Muslim League knew."{{cite book |last=Haqqani |first=Husain |title=Magnificent Delusions: Pakistan, the United States, and an Epic History of Misunderstanding |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=YP7cDQAAQBAJ&pg=PA17 |year=2015 |publisher=PublicAffairs |page=17 |isbn=978-1-61039-473-4}} His premiership lasted until 1945 when a [[motion of no confidence]] and faced with defeat in the assembly hall by 160 to 97 votes that effectively ended his premiership.{{cite book|last1=Indo-iranica|title=Indo-iranica|date=1991|publisher=Iran Society.|url=https://books.google.com/?id=h_FtAAAAMAAJ&q=khawaja+nazimuddin+Richard+Casey&dq=khawaja+nazimuddin+Richard+Casey|accessdate=20 March 2017|language=en}}{{rp|106}} He relinquished the office to [[Syed Nausher Ali|Nausher Ali]], an Indian nationalist Muslim and a prominent member of [[Indian National Congress|Congress Party]] who the speaker of the assembly, but the administration was taken over by [[Huseyn Shaheed Suhrawardy]].{{rp|106}}{{cite book|last1=Birla|first1=Krishna Kumar|title=Brushes With History|publisher=Penguin UK|isbn=9788184758511|url=https://books.google.com/?id=pDlj7rwlDK0C&pg=PT201&dq=khawaja+nazimuddin+bengal+minister+1943#v=onepage&q=khawaja%20nazimuddin%20bengal%20minister%201943&f=false|accessdate=19 March 2017|language=en}} From 1945–47, Sir Nazimuddin continued to be served as the chairman of the [[All-India Muslim League|Muslim League]] in Bengal, ardently supporting the political cause for Pakistan against the [[Indian National Congress|Congress Party]].{{rp|333}} During this time, he had been in brief conflict with Premier Suhrawardy and strongly opposed the United Bengal Movement and led a strong parliamentary opposition in the assembly against Suhrawardy's administration in April 1947. The conflict between two men mainly existed because Suhrawardy had represented the middle class while Nazimuddin was representing the aristocracy in the assembly.{{cite book |last1=Chakrabarty |first1=Bidyut |year=2004 |title=The Partition of Bengal and Assam, 1932–1947: Contour of Freedom |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=in1_AgAAQBAJ&pg=PT236 |publisher=Routledge |page=136 |isbn=978-1-134-33274-8}} In 1947, he again contested in the party elections in the Muslim League against [[Huseyn Shaheed Suhrawardy|Suhrawardy]]'s platform and securing his nomination as the party chairman for the Muslim League's East Bengal chapter.{{cite book|last1=Nair|first1=M. Bhaskaran|title=Politics in Bangladesh: A Study of Awami League, 1949–58|publisher=Northern Book Centre|isbn=9788185119793|url=https://books.google.com/?id=mB9N4oxuSY8C&pg=PA50&dq=khawaja+nazimuddin+bengal+minister+1947#v=onepage&q=khawaja%20nazimuddin%20bengal%20minister%201947&f=false|accessdate=19 March 2017|language=en}}{{rp|49–50}} His success in the party election eventually led him to the appointed as the first Chief Minister of East Bengal after the [[Partition of India|partition]] of [[India]] in 1947 and effectively gained controlled of the Muslim League in the province.{{rp|50}} As the Chief Minister, he led the motion of confidence that ultimately voted in favor of joining the [[Federation of Pakistan|federation]] of [[Pakistan]] and reorganized the [[Government of East Pakistan]] by delegating conservative members in his administration.{{rp|49–50}} ==Governor-General of Pakistan (1948–51)== On [[Fourteenth of August|14 August]] of 1947, [[Governor-General of Pakistan|Governor-General]] [[Muhammad Ali Jinnah]] relinquished the party presidency of the [[Pakistan Muslim League]] (PML) to Khawaja Nazimuddin who took over the party of [[President of Pakistan Muslim League|President]] of Pakistan Muslim League (PML), due to his party electoral performance.{{rp|50–51}} On 1 November 1947, he was appointed as [[Acting President of Pakistan|acting]] Governor-General in the absence of Governor-General Jinnah due to worsening health, and eventually appointed as Governor-General after passing of [[Muhammad Ali Jinnah]], in a crucial support provided by [[Prime Minister of Pakistan|Prime Minister]] [[Liaquat Ali Khan]] on 14 September 1948 to the President Nazimuddin.{{cite book|title=Pakistan Affairs|date=1948|publisher=Information Division, Embassy of Pakistan.|url=https://books.google.com/?id=HE8dAQAAMAAJ&q=Nazimuddin+acting+Governor&dq=Nazimuddin+acting+Governor|accessdate=20 March 2017|language=en}} His [[oath of office]] was supervised by [[Chief Justice of Pakistan|Chief Justice]] Sir [[Abdul Rashid (judge)|Abdul Rashid]] of the [[Supreme Court of Pakistan]], in attendance with Prime Minister [[Liaquat Ali Khan]]. As Governor-General, Nazimuddin set a precedent of neutrality and non-interference in the government, and provided his political support to [[Prime Minister of Pakistan|Prime Minister]] [[Liaquat Ali Khan]]'s government, which was seen as essential to the working of the [[Good governance|responsible government]] at that time.{{cite book|last1=Akbar|first1=M. K.|title=Pakistan from Jinnah to Sharif|date=1998|publisher=Mittal Publications|location=New Delhi, India|isbn=9788170996743|pages=360|edition=1|url=https://books.google.com/?id=BcIniHQAHfUC&pg=PA102&dq=Nazimuddin+Governor#v=onepage&q=Nazimuddin%20Governor&f=false|accessdate=20 March 2017|language=en|format=googlebooks|chapter=Head of State}}{{rp|102}} His role as Governor-General reflected a conservative mind-set and he spoke against [[Secularism in Pakistan|secularism]] in the country. {{Quote|text=I do not agree that religion is a private affair of the individual nor do I agree that in an Islamic state every citizen has identical rights, no matter what his caste, creed or faith be ... |author=Governor-General Khawaja Nazimuddin, 1948–49|source={{cite web|last1=Ahmed|first1=Khaled|title=Defined by exclusion|url=http://indianexpress.com/article/opinion/columns/defined-by-exclusion/|website=The Indian Express|accessdate=22 January 2016|date=22 July 2015}} }} In 1949, Governor-General Nazimuddin established the parliamentary committee, the [[Basic Principles Committee]], on the advice of Prime Minister Ali Khan to underlying basic principles that would lay foundation of [[Constitution of Pakistan|Constitution]] of [[Pakistan]].{{cite web |url=http://www.storyofpakistan.com/articletext.asp?artid=A136 |title=Basic Principles Committee |publisher=Story of Pakistan |accessdate=19 December 2013}} In 1950, Nazimuddin released an official policy statement and declared that: "Pakistan would remain incomplete until the whole of Kashmir is liberated."{{cite web|last1=Praveen|first1=Swami|title=Why Narendra Modi is smoking the Pakistani peace pipe|url=http://indianexpress.com/article/opinion/web-edits/why-narendra-modi-is-smoking-the-pakistani-peace-pipe/|website=The Indian Express|accessdate=22 January 2016|date=10 July 2015}} ==Prime Minister of Pakistan (1951–53)== ===Nazimuddin administration=== [[File:Khwaja Nazimuddin was named as the second Governor-General of Pakistan.jpg|thumb|right|150px|Nazimuddin, with [[Malik Ghulam Muhammad|M.G. Muhammad]] in [[New York City]], ca. 1948.]] After the [[Assassination of liaqat ali khan|assassination]] of [[Liaqat Ali Khan]] in 1951, the [[Pakistan Muslim League|Muslim League]] leaders asked Governor-General Nazimuddin to take over the business of the government as well as the [[President of Pakistan Muslim League|party's presidency]] as there was no other person found suitable for the post.{{cite book |last1=Noon |first1=Feroze Khan |date=1966 |title=From Memory |publisher=Ferozsons, Noon |location=Karachi, Pakistan|url=https://books.google.com/?id=1xxsSwIUPf4C&q=nazimuddin+took+overprime+minister&dq=nazimudye |accessdate=21 March 2017}}{{rp|233}} He appointed [[Finance Minister of Pakistan|Finance Minister]] [[Malik Ghulam Muhammad|Sir Malik Ghulam]] as Governor-General's post. Nazimuddin's government focused towards promoting the political programs aimed towards [[Conservatism in Pakistan|conservative ideas]].{{cite book|last1=Ispahani|first1=Farahnaz|title=Purifying the Land of the Pure: A History of Pakistan's Religious Minorities|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=9780190621674|url=https://books.google.com/?id=Jl7ODQAAQBAJ&pg=PT76&dq=nazimuddin+conservatism+ministry#v=onepage&q=nazimuddin%20conservatism%20ministry&f=false|accessdate=21 March 2017|language=en|date=2 January 2017}} During his time in office, a framework was begun for a constitution that would allow Pakistan to become a republic, and end its [[Dominion status]] under the [[British Monarchy|English monarchy]]. Nazimuddin's administration took place during a poor economy and the rise of [[Nationalism in Pakistan|provincial nationalism]] in [[Four Provinces (Pakistan)|four provinces]] and [[East Bengal]] which made him unable to run the country's affairs effectively.{{cite book|last1=Kulkarni|first1=V. B.|title=Pakistan, its origin & relations with India|date=1987|publisher=Sterling Publishers|url=https://books.google.com/?id=PT1uAAAAMAAJ&dq=nazimuddin+prime+minister+ineffective&q=Nazimuddin+|accessdate=21 March 2017|language=en}}{{rp|121–122}} By 1951–52, the [[Muslim League (Pakistan)|Muslim League]] had split into two different factions dominated by the [[Awami League|Bengali chapter]] and [[Punjab Muslim League|Punjab-Sindh chapter]], as those were the two largest ethnic demographics, but were separated by [[India]].{{rp|235}} In 1951, Prime Minister Nazimuddin's government conducted the country's first nationwide [[Census in Pakistan|census]] where it was noted that 57% population of the country was [[Indians in Pakistan|Indian immigrants]], mostly residing in [[Karachi]] that further complicated the situation in the country.{{cite book|last1=Pike|first1=Francis|title=Empires at War: A Short History of Modern Asia Since World War II|date=2011|publisher=I.B.Tauris, Pike|location=New Yorks|isbn=9780857730299|edition=2|url=https://books.google.com/?id=EKD3AgAAQBAJ&pg=PT512&dq=nazimuddin+prime+Muslim+League+split#v=onepage&q=nazimuddin%20prime%20Muslim%20League%20split&f=false|accessdate=21 March 2017|language=en|format=google books|chapter=The Night of Intellectuals}}{{rp|xxx}} In January 1952, Prime Minister Nazimuddin publicly announced in [[Dacca]]'s meeting that: [[Muhammad Ali Jinnah|Jinnah]] had been right: for the sake of [[Faith Unity Discipline|Pakistan's national unity]], [[Urdu language|Urdu]] must be the [[Languages of Pakistan|official language]] of Pakistan–[[East Pakistan|East]] and [[Geography of Pakistan|West]].{{cite book|last1=Jones|first1=Owen Bennett|title=Pakistan: Eye of the Storm|date=2001|publisher=Yale University Press|location=Yale, United States|isbn=0300101473|pages=315|url=https://books.google.com/?id=t8iYEgPYG_EC&pg=PA151&dq=Nazimuddin+census#v=onepage&q&f=false|accessdate=21 March 2017|language=en|format=google books|chapter=Bangladesh}}{{rp|153}} On 21 February 1952, a demonstration in the [[Bengali Language Movement|Bengali Language movement]] demanding equal and official status to the [[Bengali language]] turned bloody, with many fatalities caused by police firings.{{cite book|last1=Mitra|first1=Subrata Kumar|last2=Enskat|first2=Mike|last3=Spiess|first3=Clemens|title=Political Parties in South Asia|publisher=Greenwood Publishing Group|isbn=9780275968328|url=https://books.google.com/?id=dObxI9xahSYC&pg=PA137&dq=nazimuddin+took+over+prime+minister#v=onepage&q=nazimuddin%20took%20over%20prime%20minister&f=false|language=en|format=google books|chapter=The Muslim League: The decline of a national part|year=2004}}{{rp|137}} This demonstration was held when he declared Urdu the National Language of Pakistan, following the previous statement of Muhammad Ali Jinnah that Urdu shall be 'one and only' language of Pakistan.{{cite web|last1=Wali Janjua|first1=Raashid|title=Secession of East Pakistan|url=http://www.thenews.com.pk/print/82162-Secession-of-East-Pakistan|website=thenews.com.pk|accessdate=21 January 2016}} In 1953, a violent religious movement led by far-right [[Jamaat-e-Islami Pakistan|Jamaat-e-Islami]] began to agitate for the removal of the [[Ahmadi]] religious minority from power positions, and demanded a declaration of this minority as non-[[Muslims]].{{cite book|last1=Ziring|first1=Lawrence|title=Pakistan: At the Crosscurrent of History|date=2003|publisher=Oneworld|isbn=9781851683277|url=https://books.google.com/?id=cehtAAAAMAAJ&q=nazimuddin+punjab+riots&dq=nazimuddin+punjab+riots|accessdate=21 March 2017|language=en}}{{rp|60}} Nazimuddin was held morally responsible for riots being spread and resisted such pressures;{{rp|60}} but [[Lahore riots of 1953|mass rioting]] broke out in [[Punjab, Pakistan|Punjab]] against both the government and followers of this [[Ahmadiyya Muslim Community|religious minority]].{{rp|60–61}} Prime Minister Nazimuddin responded to the violence by dismissing the [[Chief Minister of Punjab (Pakistan)|Chief Minister of Punjab]], [[Mumtaz Daultana]], to [[Feroz Khan Noon]], but the decision came late.{{cite book|last1=Kukreja|first1=Veena|title=Contemporary Pakistan: Political Processes, Conflicts and Crises|publisher=SAGE|isbn=9780761996835|url=https://books.google.com/?id=gdVNL2_DUtYC&pg=PA17&dq=nazimuddin+punjab+riots#v=onepage&q=nazimuddin%20punjab%20riots&f=false|accessdate=21 March 2017|language=en|date=24 February 2003}}{{rp|17}} He declared [[Martial law in Pakistan|martial law]] and enforced through [[Lieutenant General]] [[Azam Khan (general)|Azam Khan]] who successfully quelled the agitation.{{rp|17–18}}{{cite book|last1=Mohiuddin|first1=Yasmeen Niaz|title=Pakistan: A Global Studies Handbook|publisher=ABC-CLIO|isbn=9781851098019|url=https://books.google.com/?id=OTMy0B9OZjAC&pg=PA158&dq=nazimuddin+martial+law#v=onepage&q=nazimuddin%20martial%20law&f=false|accessdate=21 March 2017|language=en|year=2007}}{{rp|158}} ==Dismissal== The agitations and violence spread through the successful [[Bengali language movement]] and the [[1953 Lahore riots|riots]] in [[Lahore]] proved the inability of Prime Minister Nazimuddin's government as he was widely seen as weak in running the government administration.{{cite book|last1=Jennings|first1=Sir Ivor|title=Constitution-Maker|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=9781107091115|url=https://books.google.com/?id=A853CgAAQBAJ&pg=PA228&dq=nazimuddin+weak#v=onepage&q=nazimuddin%20weak&f=false|accessdate=21 March 2017|language=en|date=29 January 2015}}{{rp|288}} In a view of attempting to improve the [[Economy of Pakistan|economy]] and [[Law and order in Pakistan|internal security]], [[Governor-General of Pakistan|Governor-General]] [[Malik Ghulam Muhammad|Malik Ghulam]] asked Prime Minister Nazimuddin to step down in the wider interest of the country.{{rp|289}} Prime Minister Nazimuddin refused to oblige and [[Governor-General of Pakistan|Governor-General]] [[Malik Ghulam Muhammad|Malik Ghulam]] used [[reserve power]]s granted in the [[Government of India Act, 1935]], dismissed Prime Minister Nazimuddin.{{rp|289}} Nazimuddin then requested the [[Supreme Court of Pakistan]]'s intervention against this action but the [[Chief Justice of Pakistan|Chief Justice]], [[Muhammad Munir|Moh'd Munir]] did not rule on the legality of the dismissal, but instead forced [[East Pakistani legislative election, 1954|new elections]] to be held in 1954.{{cite book|last1=Chak|first1=Farhan Mujahid|title=Islam and Pakistan's Political Culture|date=2015|publisher=Routledge|location=New York, U.S.|isbn=9781317657941|pages=180|edition=1|url=https://books.google.com/?id=xndsBAAAQBAJ&pg=PA117&dq=moulvi+tamizuddin+khan|accessdate=6 March 2017|language=en|format=googlebooks|chapter=The Constitutional cases}} [[Governor-General of Pakistan|Governor-General]] [[Malik Ghulam Muhammad|Malik Ghulam]] appointed another Bengali politician, [[Muhammad Ali Bogra]] who was then tenuring as the [[Pakistan Ambassador to the United States|Pakistan ambassador]] to the [[United States]], as the new Prime Minister until the [[East Pakistani legislative election, 1954|new elections]] to be held in 1954.{{rp|289}} The dismissal of Sir Khawaja Nazimuddin's administration, the Prime Minister, by the Governor-General [[Malik Ghulam Muhammad|Malik Ghulam]], signalled a troubling trend in [[Political history of Pakistan|political history of the country]].{{rp|289}}{{cite book|last1=Rashiduzzaman|first1=M.|title=Pakistan: A Study of Government and Politics|publisher=Ideal Library|url=https://books.google.com/?id=b-0DAAAAMAAJ&dq=khawaja+nazimuddin+ayub&q=khawaja+president|language=en|year=1967}}{{rp|132}} ==Death and legacy== ===Later life and death=== [[Image:Tomb Of Three Leader 3.A.M.R.jpg|thumb|right|Mausoleum of three leaders at [[Dhaka]]]] Even after his dismissal, he and his family remained active in parliamentary politics; his nephew, [[Khwaja Wasiuddin]], an army general serving as [[General Officer Commanding-in-Chief|GOC-in-C]] [[II Corps (Pakistan)|II Corps]] and later repatriated to [[Provisional Government of Bangladesh|Bangladesh]] in 1974. His younger brother, [[Khwaja Shahabuddin|Shahabuddin]], remained active in the politics and eventually ascended as [[Ministry of Information, Broadcasting and National Heritage (Pakistan)|Information minister]] in the [[President of Pakistan|President]] [[Ayub Khan (general)|Ayub Khan]]'s administration.{{cite book|last1=Khan|first1=Mohammad Ayub|title=Diaries of Field Marshal Mohammad Ayub Khan, 1966–1972|date=1966|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=9780195474428|url=https://books.google.com/?id=SuRtAAAAMAAJ&q=khawaja+nazimuddin+shahabuddin+ayub&dq=khawaja+nazimuddin+shahabuddin+ayub|accessdate=22 March 2017|language=en}}{{rp|559}} Sir Khawaja died in 1964, aged 70. He was buried at [[Mausoleum of three leaders]] in his hometown of Dhaka.{{cite web|url=http://www.www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GRid=15078964Cached |title=Find A Grave Memorial |accessdate=12 January 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110706155947/http://www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr |archivedate= 6 July 2011 |df= }}{{cite web|last1=Qasmi|first1=Ali Usman|title=1971 war: Witness to history|url=http://herald.dawn.com/news/1153304|website=herald.dawn.com|accessdate=21 January 2016|date=16 December 2015}}.He is considered a betrayer by Bengalis as he called the language movement protesters Communists. ===Wealth and honours=== Nazimuddin and his brother, [[Khwaja Shahabuddin|Shahabuddin]], belonged to an aristocrat wealthy family who were known for their wealth. In thesis written by Joya Chatterji, Nazimuddin was described for unquestionable loyalty to [[Viceroy of India|British administration]] in [[British Rule of India|India]]: {{Quote|text=[[Human height|Short]] statured with a bulging pear-like figure, he was known for his insatiable appetite and his unfailing submission to the .... [[British people|Britishers]]... Dressed in British-styled ''[[Sherwani]]'' and breechers-like [[Churidar|''Churidar pajamas'']] with a ''[[Fez]]'' cap and wearing little shoes, he carried a... cane of knob and represented an age and tradition.|author=Joya Chatterji, ''Bengal Divided: Hindu Communalism and Partition''|source=Reference {{rp|80}}}} By 1934, the family had estates that covered almost 200,000 acres and was well spread over seven district of [[East Bengal|Eastern Bengal]], together with Shillong and Assam with an yearly rent of [[British pound|₤]]120,000 ([[United States Dollar|$]]2,736,497.94 in 2017).{{rp|80}} By 1960s, the majority of estate was relocated from [[East Pakistan]] to the different areas of Pakistan, leaving very little of his estate in East.{{rp|80}} He was appointed a Companion of the Order of the Indian Empire (CIE) in 1926, and was [[Knight of the Order of the Star of India|knighted]] in 1934 by the [[King-Emperor]], [[George V of the United Kingdom|George V]], when he was appointed a Knight Commander of the Order of the Indian Empire (KCIE).http://www.london-gazette.co.uk/issues/34056/pages/3560 By the [[Government of Pakistan]], Nazimuddin has been honored from time to time after his death. In [[Karachi]], the residential areas, [[Nazimabad]] and [[North Nazimabad]] in suburbs of Karachi, had been named after his name. In [[Islamabad]], there is a road intersection, Nazimuddin Road, that has been named in his honor; while in Dacca, there is also a road after his namesake.{{cn|date=July 2018}} In his honour, the [[Pakistan Post]] issued a commemorative stamp in accordance to his respect.{{cite web|title=Stamp of Sir Nazimuddin|url=http://www.cybercity-online.net/pof/khawaja_nazimuddin.html}} ==See also== * [[List of Prime Ministers of Pakistan]] * [[Politics of Pakistan]] ==Notes== {{notelist}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ''Current Events Biography'', 1949 ==External links== * '''Kidding Aside''' (The British Childfree Association) was founded in 2000 and exists in order to campaign for the rights of [[United Kingdom|British]] [[childfree]] people. It is thought to be the first politically active childfree movement in the world{{Fact|date=February 2007}} and strives to introduce the childfree voice into relevant British political debate. It also works to promote the childfree [[lifestyle (sociology)|lifestyle]] as a legitimate and equal alternative to [[parenting|parenthood]], and campaigns for equality of opportunity for childfree people in employment and with regard to UK tax legislation. In addition to the voluntary childfree, the issues Kidding Aside speaks on also affect the lives of those who are involutarily childfree.
== See also == * [[No Kidding!]]
== References == *[http://jobsadvice.guardian.co.uk/officehours/story/0,14369,1253903,00.html "When Parents Get Priority" Guardian July 5, 2004] *[http://observer.guardian.co.uk/focus/story/0,6903,1212597,00.html "Baby, what Shall I Do?" Observer May 9, 2004] *[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/4813590.stm "The Rise of the 'Childfree'" BBC News March 31, 2006]
==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20020816192436/http://www.kiddingaside.net/ Kidding Aside website]

{{more footnotes|date=November 2017}} '''Leonard Hodgson''' (24 October 1889 in [[Fulham]], [[London]] – 15 July 1969 in [[Leamington Spa]]) was an [[Anglican]] [[priest]], [[philosopher]], [[theologian]], [[historian]] of the early Church and [[Regius Professor of Divinity]] at the [[University of Oxford]] from 1944 to 1958.
==Early life == Hodgson was the son of Walter Hodgson (1853–1934), a shorthand writer to the [[House of Lords]] and the [[British House of Commons|House of Commons]], and of his wife Lillias Emma, a daughter of William Shaw of [[County Durham]]. He was educated at [[St Paul's School (London)|St Paul's School]], London, and [[Hertford College, Oxford]], where he took a second in Classical Moderations (Greek and Latin) in 1910, a first in [[Literae Humaniores|Greats ]] (Philosophy and Ancient History) in 1912 and a first in [[Theology]] in 1913.<ref>''Oxford University Calendar 1914'', Oxford : Clarendon Press, 1914, pp.198, 209, 230.</ref> He then trained for the ministry at [[St Michael's College, Llandaff|St Michael's College]], [[Llandaff]].
==Career== He was [[ordination|ordained]] a deacon of the [[Church of England]] in 1913, after a year at Llandaff. He served briefly as a curate at St Mark's Church, [[Portsmouth]], then in 1914, in a meteoric promotion, he became vice-principal of [[St Edmund Hall, Oxford]]. In 1919 he was elected tutor in theology and dean of divinity at [[Magdalen College, Oxford]]. He was appointed professor of Christian apologetics the [[General Theological Seminary]], [[New York City]], in 1925. He was a canon of [[Winchester]] from 1931 to 1938, when he was elected as [[Regius Professor of Moral and Pastoral Theology]] and canon of [[Christ Church, Oxford]].
During the 1930s he became an active [[ecumenist]] and served on the Anglican Council on Foreign Relations. He was also general secretary of the Edinburgh world conference on faith and order in 1937. From 1944 to 1958, he was Oxford's [[Regius Professor of Divinity]]. Twice nominated for episcopal office, he declined to become [[Bishop of Carlisle]], and also refused the bishopric of [[Monmouth]] in 1940 in a move<ref>Peart-Binns J.S, 1990: Edwin Morris, Archbishop of Wales, Llandyssul, Gomer Press.</ref> which some in the Church in Wales believe deprived the Province of a new and invigorating presence among its prelates. He delivered the Gifford lectures, ''For Faith and Freedom'', from 1955 to 1957 at [[Glasgow University]]. From 1954 until 1966 (some of this time overlapping with his positions in Oxford) he was Warden of William Temple College, [[Rugby, Warwickshire|Rugby]]. In his book ''Sex and Christian Freedom'' (1967) he tried to "talk twentieth-century common sense without being disloyal to our ordination vows".
===Career summary=== *Curate of St Mark's Church, [[Portsmouth]], 1913-1914 *Vice-Principal of [[St Edmund Hall, Oxford]], 1914-1919 *Examining chaplain to the [[Bishop of Lichfield]], 1917 to 1925 *Official Fellow and Dean of Divinity, [[Magdalen College, Oxford]], 1919-1925 *Professor of Christian Apologetics, [[General Theological Seminary]], [[New York City]], 1925-1931 *Residentiary Canon of [[Winchester Cathedral]] 1931-1938 *Examining chaplain to the [[Bishop of Winchester]], 1932 to 1939 *Theological Secretary to the Commission on Faith and Order of the [[World Council of Churches]], 1933 to 1952 *Regius Professor of Moral and Pastoral Theology and Canon of [[Christ Church, Oxford]], 1938-1944 *Regius Professor of Divinity and Canon of Christ Church, Oxford, 1944-1958 *Warden of William Temple College, [[Rugby, Warwickshire|Rugby]], 1954-1966 *Member of council of [[St David's College, Lampeter]]
==Family== In 1917, Hodgson proposed unsuccessfully to the novelist [[Dorothy L. Sayers]]. On 7 April 1920 he married Ethel Margaret du Plat (1888–1960), the daughter of the Rev. C. F. Archer, Rector of [[Moy, County Tyrone|Moy]], [[County Tyrone]]. They had a son and a daughter.
==Major publications== *''The Place of Reason in Christian Apologetic'' (1925) *''Nestorius, The Bazaar of Heracleides'' (with [[G. R. Driver]], 1925) *[https://archive.org/details/MN41408ucmf_6 ''And was made Man''] (1928) *''Essays in Christian Philosophy'' (1930) *''Eugenics'' (1933) *''The Lord's Prayer'' (1934) *''Democracy and Dictatorship in the Light of Christian Faith'' (1935) *''The Grace of God in Faith and Philosophy'' (Paddock lectures, 1936) *''This War and the Christian'' (1939) *''The Christian Idea of Liberty'' (1941) *''Towards a Christian Philosophy'' (1942) *''The Doctrine of the Trinity'' (1943) *''Theology in an Age of Science'' (1944) *''The Doctrine of the Church'' (1946) *''Biblical Theology and the Sovereignty of God'' (1947) *''Christian Faith and Practice'' (1950) *''The Doctrine of the Atonement'' (1951) *''For Faith and Freedom'' (1956) (1955-57 [[Gifford Lectures]], Glasgow; 1968 edition: [https://web.archive.org/web/20080621163750/http://www.giffordlectures.org/Browse.asp?PubID=TPFFAF&Cover=TRUE Vol. 1], [https://web.archive.org/web/20080621163548/http://www.giffordlectures.org/Browse.asp?PubID=TPFFAM&Cover=TRUE Vol. 2]) *''Church and Sacraments in Divided Christendom'' (1959) *''The Bible and the Training of the Clergy'' (1963) *''Sex and Christian Freedom'' (1967)
==Honours== *Hon. [[Doctor of Civil Laws]], [[Bishop's University]], [[Lennoxville]], [[Canada]], 1929 *Hon. [[Doctor of Sacred Theology]], [[General Theological Seminary]], [[New York City]], 1931 *[[Doctor of Divinity]], Oxford University, 1938 *Hon. Doctor of Divinity, [[Edinburgh University]], 1938 *Hon. Doctor of Divinity, [[Glasgow University]], 1956 *Hon. fellow of [[St Edmund Hall, Oxford]], 1957 *Hon. fellow of [[Selwyn College, Cambridge]], 1957 *Emeritus Student, [[Christ Church, Oxford]], 1959
==References== {{Reflist}}
==Further reading== *''Hodgson, Leonard (1889–1969), theologian'' by Mark D. Chapman in [[Dictionary of National Biography|Oxford Dictionary of National Biography]] *''HODGSON, Rev. Leonard, DD STD Hon. DCL'' in ''Who Was Who 1897-2006''

{{about|meaningless rhetoric|the literary use|Nonsense verse}} {{Unreferenced|date=December 2009}}
A '''meaningless statement''' posits nothing of substance with which one could agree or disagree. In the context of [[logical argument]]s, the inclusion of a meaningless statement in the premises will undermine the validity of the argument since that premise can neither be true nor false.
There are many classes of meaningless statement:
* A statement may be considered meaningless if it asserts that two categories are disjoint without proposing a criterion to distinguish between them. For example, the claim, "I wouldn't know how [[pornography]] differs from [[erotica]]" is a [[distinction without a difference]]. * A statement may be meaningless if its terms are undefined, or if it contains unbound variables. For instance, the sentence "All ''X'' have ''Y''" is meaningless unless the terms ''X'' and ''Y'' are defined (or bound). * A grammatically correct sentence may be meaningless if it ascribes properties to particulars which admit of no such properties. For example, the famous sentence "[[Colorless green ideas sleep furiously]]" cannot be taken literally. * An ungrammatical sentence admits of no meaning. For instance, the string of words "deities Olympus Greek reside The. upon" offers no information regarding the Greek deities, or their whereabouts. * [[Lewis Carrol]]'s poem [[Jabberwocky]] is a famous example of the [[nonsense verse|nonsensical as literature]].
==See also== * [[Non sequitur (logic)]] * [[Nonsense]]

'''Mikhail Fedotovich Ovsyannikov''' ({{lang-ru|Михаи́л Федо́тович Овся́нников}}; 21 November 1915{{spaced ndash}}11 August 1987) was a [[Soviet Union|Soviet]] philosopher and academic who concentrated on in-depth study of [[Georg Wilhelm Friedrich Hegel]].<ref>Cf. Ovsyannikov, M.F. ''Гегель'' (''Hegel''). Moscow: Mysl, 1971. {{ru icon}}</ref> Ovsyannikov was head of the Philosophy Department at [[Moscow State University]] from 1968 to 1974.
==Biography== Ovsyannikov was born 21 November 1915 in the settlement of [[Manturovsky District, Kursk Oblast|Puzachi]] in the [[Russian Empire|Imperial Russian]] [[Kursk Governorate]] (presently in [[Kursk Oblast]]). He completed a degree at V.I. Lenin Moscow State Pedagogical University in 1939, subsequently earning a ''[[Kandidat nauk]]'' (primary-level doctoral degree) in 1943 for a dissertation titled "The Fate of Art in the Capitalist Milieu of Hegel and [[Balzac]]" («Судьба искусства в капиталистическом обществе у Гегеля и Бальзака»). In 1961 he earned the academic title ''[[Doktor nauk]]'' (higher-level doctoral degree) for ''The Philosophy of Hegel'', coming to be exceptionally regarded as a specialist on the critical analysis of Hegel's works.
From 1960, Ovsyannikov directed [[Marxist philosophy|Marxist research]] in aesthetics at Moscow State; he chaired the philosophy department from 1960 to 1974, teaching the history of philosophy and courses on philosophical developments outside the Soviet Union. He was the general editor of Moscow State University's philosophy journal from 1969 to 1983.
==Major works== * ''Философия Гегеля'' (1959) * ''Гегель'' (1971) * ''Проблемы художественного творчества'' (1975) * ''История эстетической мысли'' (1983)
== References == {{reflist}}
== External links == * [http://leninist.biz/en/1969/POMA347/09-The.Artistic.Image “The Artistic Image”] (1969)

{{Japanese name|Miyake}} {{nihongo|'''Miyake Setsurei'''|三宅 雪嶺||July 7, 1860 - November 26, 1945}} was a famous philosopher and author from Japan. He graduated from the [[University of Tokyo]]'s Department of Philosophy in 1883. He helped found the Society for Political Education and its magazine "Nihonjin" (Japanese People). In 1907 the [[Nihonjin Magazine]] was renamed "Nihon Oyobi Nihonjin" (Japan and The Japanese People). It was at this time that [[Hasegawa Nyozekan]] was recruited to the magazine.
Miyake's other works included "[[Shinzenbi Nihonjin]]" (Goodness, truth and beauty of The Japanese People) and "[[Giakushu Nihonjin]]" (Falsehoods, evil and ugliness of the Japanese People).
==Political views== Miyake was a Cooperative Nationalist and differed in opinion from Universalists. He felt that Japan was first a member of the Asian community and secondly a member of the global community. Also Japan should hold onto and preserve its cultural heritage from before the Meiji era as it helped to strengthen Asian culture and, by doing so, world culture.
Miyake felt Japan should make it its mission to study Asia, oppose western imperialism, and nurture the distinctive Japanese sense of beauty.
